context: Muammar <a4_0>Gaddafi <a0_0>was born in a tent near Qasr Abu Hadi, a rural area outside the town of <a9_0>Sirte<a9_0/> in the deserts of western Libya<a4_0/><a0_0/>. His family came from a small, relatively un-influential tribal group called the <a10_0>Qadhadhfa<a10_0/>, who were Arabized Berber in heritage. <a8_0>His father, Mohammad Abdul Salam bin Hamed bin Mohammad, was known as <a11_0>Abu Meniar<a11_0/> (died 1985), and his mother was named Aisha (died <a12_0>1978<a12_0/>)<a8_0/>; <a5_0>Abu Meniar earned a meager subsistence as a goat and camel herder<a5_0/>. <a6_0>Nomadic Bedouins, they were illiterate and kept no birth records<a6_0/>. As such, <a2_0>Gaddafi's date of birth is not known with certainty, and sources have set it in 1942 or in the spring of 1943<a2_0/>, although biographers Blundy and Lycett noted that it could have been pre-1940. His parents' only surviving son, he had <a13_0>three<a13_0/> older sisters. Gaddafi's upbringing in <a3_0>Bedouin<a3_0/> culture influenced his personal tastes for the rest of his life. <a1_0><a7_0>He repeatedly expressed a preference for the desert over the city and retreated to the desert to meditate.
